annotation.TEXT: I may as well mention this now while I have the chance: Originally I was going to use Proto Man for this run, but after testing him out, I didn't have much of a choice but to pick a different character. The main reason is because Proto Man is almost the equivalent to Owata (on hard mode, at least). He takes so much damage per hit that he may as well not have a health bar at all.

"Ignorance" isn't exactly the worst boss in the game, but I still don't care much for his gimmick. You can't damage him until you knock his head off (which seems to serve as a shield generator for his main body). The aspect of his body becoming more damaged as the fight goes on is kind of interesting, but I think there's easily more that could have been done with this concept than what's used here.

I was considering playing as Bass again, but I eventually decided against it. The main reason for this is that even on the hardest difficulty, he still makes the game a bit too easy. I eventually decided on Mega Man even though I really wanted to mix it up for this playthrough (maybe Proto Man will get his chance another time, in a game where he can actually handle taking a hit).

He also gives a ton of opportunities to deal damage to him (way more than any other Devil boss I know of, fan-game or otherwise). Given this, the collapsing ceiling doesn't really come into play during this fight, unless you somehow mess up royally on hitting him for about 5 phases in a row.

Under normal circumstances, beating all 4 of the main bosses will take you to the final battle. If you're playing on hard mode however, the game will present you with one extra fight before going off to face Wily...

"Want" is nearly in the same category as Scrooge, only he thankfully doesn't have a healing move. Despite this, his fight still manages to be unnecessarily chaotic at times. It also doesn't help that his weakness is specifically designed for enemies within vertical range, when Want himself spends most of the time on the ground.

Despite only showing up on hard mode, the Light Devil is actually pretty easy to deal with. He functions like a normal devil for the most part, only most of his projectiles come in the form of gifts with two different variations (ones that slide across the ground, and ones that bounce). He can still fire shots from his eyes, but he only ever does this when he gets down to half health. Interestingly enough, his eye-lasers can also destroy his own gifts.

Tiny Tim is definitely the easiest boss in the game (even without his weakness). He can make the fight a bit cramped with how close he'll get at times, but he won't outright move into you unless he's preparing to use his crushing attack.

Much like in the last game, I'll be using the code that unlocks pretty much every weapon from the start (though skipping the silly name entry this time). The major difference is that I'll be playing as Mega Man for this run, and that I'll actually be using the weapons more often.

Scrooge is, by far, the most frustrating boss in the game. He jumps whenever you try to shoot him, and if you do manage to hit him, he'll create a spread shot immediately afterwards. He can also toss out exploding coins in a seemingly random pattern (which will sometimes cover the whole screen). In the middle of all this, he can also use a health-draining move that can sometimes hit you through invincibility frames.

Another thing to note is that this game has a scoring system similar to the first one. Once again, most of these have been edited out for the sake of convenience (the online leaderboard is still down as well, which makes the overall score pointless either way).

As mentioned before, this game follows the same formula as the first one, in that it's a boss rush from start to finish. Unlike the first game however, I'm not beyond using weapons more often in this one. To put it bluntly: I find the sequel's bosses to be far more annoying when compared to the original's. Most of them just aren't worth the headache of trying to buster-duel them (especially if you're Proto Man).
Pictured: Rubber Duff's only use in this game. Seriously, don't use it for anything else, not even against Ignorance despite it being his weakness (it's just that terrible of a weapon).

For those of you wondering, the Marley symbol on the clock is actually related to a hidden achievement you can get during this fight. Using all of the weapons from the previous game's bosses on Scrooge (in order of their appearance in the original story) will cause said bosses to emerge and slowly drain his health. It's a neat secret to be sure, but the Marley Chain alone is far quicker and more effective.

This is actually one of the hidden achievements in this game (and probably the easiest to find). I was planning on showing a few more, but most of them revolved around reflecting things for entire fights with Proto Man.

The Wily fight in this game is a bit...odd. It technically has three phases: The two turrets at the bottom, the tree, and then Wily himself. All of them have easily exploitable weaknesses and can go down in mere seconds if you know how to utilize them. Even without them however, this is actually a pretty simple fight (barring the enemies the second phase generates, which tend to be annoying if anything).

Time to get started on the sequel to the previous game. To be honest, it's actually not all that different in overall premise and functions when compared to the first one. With that being said however, I will be doing things a bit differently in terms of play-style for this game.
